bibl.title: Letter from Arthur Bevan to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1940

div1.p: Bevan writes that he will help estimate the ages of the framboyant trees, but notes that dating them will be difficult.

div1.head: Letter from Arthur Bevan to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1940
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
FOREST SERVICE
TROPICAL FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION
RIO PIEDRAS, PUERTO RICO
October 2, 1940
FOREST STATION
U S
ADDRESS REPLY TO
DIRECTOR
AND REFER TO
R - TR
INFORMATION
Inquiries
Fors
Beuvan
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of August 28 to the Chief of the Forestry Department
in Washington and a copy of Dr. Haig's reply of September 12 have been
forwarded to this office.

Your problem is extremely interesting and although such questions
are always hard to answer, I like to feel that there is some possibility
of working out a proper solution. First, it should be easier for someone
in Cuba to estimate the ages of these trees than we in Puerto Rico. This,
of course, you tried to do by looking for a tree expert in Havana. At any
rate, I am listing the following names of men, there in Cuba, who might be
able to help you in the event that you wish to try farther along that
line. They are as follows:
Mr. Alberto J. Fors
Encargado de Viveros Forestales
Habana, Cuba
Mr. Juan Tomás Roig, Jefe
Departamento de Química
Estación Experimental Agronómica
Santiago de las Vegas, Habana, Cuba
Mr. Julián Acuña, Jefe
Departamento de Botánica
Estación Experimental Agronómica
Santiago de las Vegas, Habana, Cuba
Mr. F. G. Walsingham
Asst. Supt., Harvard Gardens
Apartado 251 (Soledad)
Cienfuegos, Cuba

Now, as for what we might do here from the photographs, brings up
the following considerations. We have in Puerto Rico a great many
Flamboyant trees growing under a wide range of climatic conditions and
- 2 -
it is possible that we can find trees whose planting date may be
definitely determined for comparison with the Cuban trees which you
photographed. In that event, it is necessary for us to know as far
as possible the conditions of the site where these grew.

Let me then write a bit about the growth of the Flamboyant tree.
This species grows rapidly and soon attains its maximum height. The
height of the tree, whether in a photograph or seen in the field, will
not be an indication of its age, but will be an indication of the
conditions of the site, since the species on poor sites will not attain
as great a height for any given age as another tree of the same species
on a more fertile or more protected site. Thus, both the question of
soil depth and soil fertility as well as protection from winds come into
the picture. If we had the photographs alone, we will have to use the
heights of the trees as an indication of the quality of the site, as it
is supposed that both camp sites are within the same general climatic
section of rainfall and temperature. However, if you can give us any
further information as to the exposure of these trees to the wind and
as to the conditions of the soil, whether apparently worn out and rocky
or deep and fertile, this will be of considerable assistance.

This site factor is extremely important since it would very well
be possible for a tree of greater diameter on a good site to be much
younger than a tree of smaller diameter on a poor site.

Fortunately, you are asking about a species which does grow over
a wide range of climatic conditions. When this is true, minor factors
of the site affect the tree much less than it does to those species
which are extremely particular as to sites, and grow within a very narrow
range of conditions. For example, Spanish cedar is very particular and
we may get, within a few feet of each other in plantations, trees with a
tremendous difference in diameter even though of the same age. In the
Flamboyant, this factor is practically eliminated and provided there is
no competition from other trees, we have much better chance of correlating
the diameter with age. I am supposing, of course, that it will be
possible to estimate the diameters from your photographs. This, we have
been able to do before where a human figure was close to the tree and it
was possible to compare these and obtain the diameter of the trunk within
at least 2 inches. However, I do not wish to be too optimistic about the
possibilities of arriving at the approximate ages of these trees. If the
dates of planting of these two trees were relatively close together it
may be very difficult to say with any certainty which tree is older. At
any rate, if you wish to send us the photographs and any other information
about the sites which is available, we will certainly be glad to do what
we can or will advise you that it is impossible for us to make any state-
ment which would be of value to you.

closer.signed:
ARTHUR BEVAN, Director
By L. R. Holdridge Acting
